transcription.text: [ Music ]
>> Good morning.
I'm excited to be here this morning.
And to guide you through what I see as an exciting development.
So I'm here to introduce you, or better yet let Cortana, introduce you to the Galaxy's largest playground for blockchain developers.
So Microsoft Azure is a hyperscale global cloud platform that has the fundamentals to provide you for infrastructure services.
Like virtual machines and storage and networking, but so much more.
Microsoft when began the cloud journey we actually overshot the marketplace and developed and focused our attention on platform of the service.
Essentially building a fabric of APIs that don't have any dependents on particular VMs and instances.
Rather you just declarably program what is your intentions.
So we have a huge portfolio of these platform services that you see here.
Now why am I showing you these platform services instead of focusing on VMs.
Platform services are the future.
Worrying about your VMs and what their sizes are and their capabilities are really a thing of the past.
We are rather getting to a point where you're declaring in software what your hardware dependencies and needs are.
So with this for blockchain developers I'm just going to point out a couple of these.
This is an eye chart slide and believe me this eye chart slide has been condensed and simplified.
It's a much larger ecosystem.
But you can see some of these services like notification hubs, machine learning which we have rebranded into Cortana analytics.
It brings machine learning to the masses and makes it achievable in surfacing machine learning capabilities for prediction markets around the world.
The event hubs, the key vault, say crypto is very important.
We offer a key vault that has a unique service we think will be of interest to this community.
And then Active Direct where we talk a little bit about identity and federated identity.
How do we first establish identity and how do we allow you to have composite identities.
That is a very important thing.
When I talk about Azure I'm going to talk about size for a minute.
So this is about one building.
This building is very large.
I don't know if you can see the scale here.
Oops.
I can't pinch and zoom because it's projecting.
But anyway, you can see the cars over there.
This is one building in a typical data center in Azure.
Each data center of the new data centers have four of these buildings connected at each location.
We are adding a million cores.
That's our run rate.
Every time I say it's a million cores a year we up that.
So we're growing very, very rapidly in this space.
This is just one data center, one quarter of a data center.
These data centers do span the globe.
When we talk about what's there we are talking about hyperscale global network.
The ones in green that are highlighted are coming online later this year.
You can see we basically covered the world.
Where we find a need, particularly if it's regulatory, there's a demand from our customers.
We'll plop a data center in there.
We have data centers in China.
We have data centers coming into Canada this year.
Now, Azure is an open cloud.
It is the most open cloud, I would argue.
We are not the old Microsoft.
This is the new Microsoft.
We embrace open source.
We actually contribute a great deal to some of the most innovative features coming with cloud.
I want to talk about ones that I think are very strategic to what we're trying to do here with Ethereum and our partners.
All of this is available to you in Azure.
You pick and choose the flavor of OS that you want.
Forget about the OS.
You have to pick and choose the database, the platform, the blockchain, the UI, whatever.
Whatever your dev tools are, we'll support it.
Again, this is hyperscale enterprise cloud.
Before the Red Hat announcement, which was last week, I believe, we announced Red Hat availability for our enterprise customers and really anybody.
One in four of our VMs were Linux.
We expect that to about double.
It will be about half of our VMs will be Linux based running in the cloud.
Now, I would be remiss in talking about regulatory compliance.
For those of you that target enterprise customers, they do tend to care about this stuff.
We are the most compliant cloud and have the largest portfolio of certifications in the world.
None of our competitors are going to test this.
There's one I put in the question mark about the safe harbor.
We'll see what happens there.
I guarantee you, if there is a certification to be had, we will get it.
If there is a regulatory hurdle to jump, we will jump it.
There will not be a blocker for Azure moving forward.
What is blockchain as a service?
What are we intending to do?
The first thing we are doing at the enterprise level, we are targeting primarily our enterprise
customers, but really this benefits the entire development community.
We are creating a set of services that allow our customers to fail fast.
Most of our enterprise customers cannot afford to take the jump particularly into Ethereum or
blockchain and use a parachute when they jump out to playing.
They need to fall fast and hit the ground fast.
If they fail, fail early and they get back up and try it again.
How do they do that with IT infrastructures and budgets and constraints?
It's expensive.
They are too slow.
We want our customers and our developers to be able to experiment rapidly at low cost to
spin up resources on demand and experiment by mixing and matching different frameworks,
different platforms, different tools to create the most awesome Ethereum based applications.
We talk about creating private Ethereum environments, how do they do that rapidly, supporting the
public network going back and forth.
Eventually, we are creating that platform to evolve as this technology evolves to be able
to make sure that the services that you need are there.
The biggest hurdle I always hear from customers is getting started.
I remember July 31 when Frontier came out, I spent the better part of two days sitting
in my office trying to get the damn thing up and running.
Fortunately, I was using Windows, which is even worse.
Once I switched to Ubuntu, I was a little bit more successful.
We'll try to fix that, by the way.
We want to make it very easy.
One-click deployment.
If you have not seen Azure, I will show it to you in a moment.
The Azure has a portal that our developers and IT pros go to create and manage resources
that are going to be used in the cloud.
We are going to be introducing -- this is what I call a soft launch.
This is a developer audience.
You guys will forgive me if I show you GitHub and things like that.
I did a hard launch, it would be all polished in marketing.
We wouldn't show you any -- I would not definitely show you an SSH shell or anything like that.
Here, we will show you what the vision is and show you what it looks like at this moment.
This blockchain category will be up here.
You will notice we have some pre-populated items up here.
We are talking about the blockchain as a service, particularly the Ethereum blockchain as a service or FPass.
It is provided by consensus.
Consensus is launching today two basic packages in this marketplace.
The marketplace will consist of a private loopback, if you will,
private blockchain environment based off of the Go implementation.
With one-click, you will install a private network that has a pre-fueled ether account.
You can go ahead and our intention is to have someone, a newbie,
and these enterprise customers to, with one-click, be able to deploy and get up and stand up in a Ethereum environment.
Follow a simple script and write their first smart contract application within 20 minutes.
If you had told me that on the 31st time, it probably come to tears.
Because of the amount of time I spent on learning how not to do it.
We want to make it much easier.
We envision our customers picking from this menu.
This menu, when it says "blockchains", we kept it unique.
We want services that apply, even if you are not providing a full blockchain stack,
if you are not doing this C++ implementation or the Go implementation or the Java implementation.
You have a service that you have written that is specifically designed to work with Ethereum networks.
You should publish it here to make it discoverable.
We are creating this category.
You can go through any one of these and I will walk you through what it looks like.
If you wanted to have a private blockchain, for instance, it has six nodes,
one node in the east coast of the United States, one in Europe, one in China, one in Japan, and one in Singapore, you could do that.
All within filling up one wizard and click deploy, you would be up and running within minutes.
That is amazingly powerful.
Let me show you what this looks like.
The marketplace is real fast.
This is what the Azure portal looks like.
I am using the Batman theme.
It does come in black.
I will come in here and I will say new.
I will create a new Ubuntu.
That is what I have been using lately.
I will create here and show you what this looks like.
I will go through this process because I am showing you creating a VM from Ubuntu.
That is not exciting.
I will show you what it is going to look like to create one of these blockchain assets.
I want to point out a couple of things.
Let me pick a different region and show you how bad as a machine I can create.
Let's say I am really going to be aggressive with this.
I want to say create a -- let's see how much money I want to spend.
There we go.
This looks good.
32 cores and 448 gigs.
That looks good to me.
You can see I can pick and choose from a menu of these type of resources.
Go ahead and type in a host name.
That is not going to work.
That is not going to work either.
I cannot use spaces.
I can configure this and say go.
We will go out and provision this and create it.
For the quick start you will see when I told you that for the Ethereum blockchains, we have
not stood up the blockchain category yet.
That will happen probably by the end of the month.
You do see this is the Azure marketplace.
I will touch on this blockchain strato.
I will show you the one click deploy for deploying blockchain.
I will create this block out strato image.
This is based on Ubuntu and it has the full stack.
I will log in really quick.
It is going to fire up.
It is going to fire up right into the template for me to fill in my parameters for my new
blockchain environment that I want to spin up.
As we come up and this is live, I am not chewing a video or anything here.
I will name this.
I am going to type in some stuff here.
I am going to go on the dev network and put it in a password and say okay.
It will spin up and create it.
I will let these guys do it live.
Let me switch back to my slides really quick and give you the big picture.
Let's talk about the technology that is going to change the way we deliver these types of
services and deliver this value.
The first is containers.
Namely docker and windows containers.
They are basically interchangeable at this point.
The amount of work we have done with docker to make container technology ubiquitous across
Linux and windows distributions and have a single management platform and deployment
platform working with the Apache foundation.
We have created an environment where you can mix and match VMs and containers to get the
right environment for you at the drop of a half and be able to change things almost
instantly and deploy and scale based on your needs and demand.
Remember, this is azure.
If you are not familiar with azure, azure is a subscription service.
You only pay for what you use.
It is not like getting a cable TV package or a cell phone package.
You only pay for what you use.
We have these containers.
A container, if you are not familiar with docker, it runs within a vm or it can run on
the hypervisor itself.
We are creating an image repository.
These are going to have containers that have pre-packaged, like say, a stack for
Ethereum, a particular stack, you can have 10, 20, 30 different types of stacks that
you can mix and match.
Select those from the image repository and spin up on your platform the stack that
you are wanting to build upon.
Where this leads us is to this broader vision for blockchains.
The Ethereum blockchain is a service vision with containers and the ability to
dynamically spin up these type of resources.
We envision an era of microservices.
Microservices, we are really decomposing.
Let me go back to the talk yesterday.
The capability so that you can quickly compose solutions and be able to look at
these different capabilities in this service fabric and be able to begin
developing blockchain-based applications, consuming and exposing these other
additional value added services such that the blockchain development and the
ecosystem becomes a much richer environment for enterprise customers.
My question for you is as you look at this type of environment and noting that in
the back, if you grab one of those big posters, it has a $200 certificate.
It is like winning the lottery.
You get that big check that you can't do anything with.
You don't have to take the poster book.
Everyone that says attendance will have the ability to get a $200 credit for
Azure to be able to evaluate this and start building your apps and looking at
building Ethereum APIs, blockchain APIs, crypto services, whatever you can dream of
to build on this platform.
My question to you is what will you add?
Thank you.
[Applause]
